reviewText:
I really hesitated before writing this, but I have to admit, that this game is a failure, even after taking under consideration it's price.

Game mechanics:The game isn't, as it adverises itself, a roguelike game - only thing that is 'random' is loot. Dungeon location, and dungeons themselves remains the same for all gamethroughs, up to a point that I can pretty much play this game blindfolded. Room-swapping screen movement is terrible - you will pretty much take free damage to face, if not blocked.

Equipment loot varies a lot - from 'totally useless' to 'oh god i got it at lvl 2 and i can just hack my way through the game from this point'. There's nothing clever about stats, nothing interesting about armors and weapons, besides hammers scaling with faith.

Respawn and 'second chance' system is something new. It isn't actually doing anything but making an excuse for not fixing screen-swapping nearly unavoidable damage. It doesn't make this game any easier - it makes it bearable.

Fighting system is garbage. All you have to do is run into enemies, and sometimes - if you didn't get good loot - click on them. Done. It couldn't be any easier.

Level design:Level design is lacking pretty much everything - you get:
Icy, forgotten,  something plagued area!
Spooky forest with spooky ghosts!
Desert with giant insects!
Purple land with purple Striders from Half-Life 2! RIGHT NEXT TO EACH OTHER.
There's a locked last level, unlocked after going through all dungeons. It's spookier than the forest, more plagued than Africa and icy area combined, with more irritating enemies than Middle East and desert all together. Also, caves.
Everything here just screams 'lazy', but what would you expect after a 5€ game (Hint - more)?

Bosses and enemies:Oh God, here's a good one. I guess omnipresent knights are supposed to be like Black Phantoms from DS. If so, they fail in that role.
Want a quick hint on how to defeat all bosses? Just click them to death. Simple as it sounds, it's true. There's little to add to this game.

Overall look:Good time killer, terrible game. Doesn't live up to its description.
Don't buy it, unless it's for on a discount. For real. It's not worth 5€.

While it was interesting to try out, the game needs a revision on some of its mechanics.  The lack of any map ensures you'll spend a lot of time wandering around, and it's probably the single biggest sticking point of the game that I can think of.  Other than that, most dungeons had similar or identical layouts, and trekking back to a dungeon after a death turns into a chore when you're not positive which way to go.  After about an hour my mind started to glaze over because the game starts to numb you - each screen looks similar, contains similar enemies, and must be handled in a similar way.\n\nThe game's concept is great but it will quickly get old unless something is done in a patch to revisit some of its weaknesses.  I can't recommend the game for its full retail price, but if you're OK with paying 3 dollars or so to wring out about 2 hours of fun, then you'll have a good time.  After spending about 2 hours in the game I have no desire to continue playing it - the rogue-like elements are far from deep and the inspirations from Dark Souls and Zelda do not significantly change or improve upon aspects of those games. Instead, the very clear inspiration it takes from other games leaves these borrowed mechanics feel shallow in comparison to their use in the titles that made them classics.
BITS, BATS, AND BEGONIAS!

I played the original bit Dungeon on my phone a year ago and was pretty excited to hear a sequal was in the works. bit Dungeon II is vastly superior to its predecesor. I will say it does have some faults though.
The general gameplay is a roguelike 2D zelda style. You don't have a story really but you have an overworld with dungeons spread throughout and a few very basic random events that can happen such as being attacked when healing at a fireplace. Enemies and bosses are mostly simple but some have special attacks that must be avoided and you'll randomly find dungeons where enemies are harder than you may expect.

Overall the gameplay is addicting and fun. Many of the items can have cool stats that allow you to do fun setups with your character. The thing the game truly suffers from is how simple the controls are. This is due to it being a game designed for phones. You can use your keyboard to play which is a simple WASD and spacebar setup however this can be annoying when your attack button is the same way you pick up gear. I have often dropped my items on accident. This is worse when you don't realize it and move off the screen and anything on the ground vanishes. These are things that can be fixed though and hopefully will be.

Another thing is imbalance. The bow is absurdly overly powered. If you don't want to make the game too easy I suggest avoiding it. If you want to get further into the game then pick one up. Using the spacebar you can spam the bow many times before running out of energy.

Anywho for the low price the game is very much worth getting, and I find it more enjoyable on the PC with the keyboard than on the phone with the touchscreen.
The game uses direction keys and one button for attack. The controls felt loose/inconsistent for this kind of tightly focused game. Not what I'm looking for, unfortunately.

4/10

bit Dungeon II is a minimalistic roguelike that pays homage to games like The Legend of Zelda. Upon loading the game, you feel like you're in for a fun, difficult, nostalgia-inducing treat that will keep you hooked for hours. Sadly, this isn't necessarily the case. bit Dungeon II is fun for the first 15 to 20 minutes of playing, but it quickly wears thin of its flare. One button to attack, block, and perform special abilities while you explore dungeons that are vastly the same as the previous.

The description of bit Dungeon II mentions Dark Souls, a brutal third-person game where death is inevitable and unforgiving; I expected the same experience from bit Dungeon II. While you may have a similar experience while playing with sword and shield, you'll find that archers are ridiculously overpowered. It's too easy to just sit in a corner, where monsters won't even notice you, and then just spam arrows into their backs. When using a bow, even the bosses become a cakewalk. The only downside to using a bow is the boring downtime you have while waiting for your stamina to regenerate. Fully depleting your stamina for the first time while fighting a boss introduces an interesting element when you notice that your tiny dungeon crawler is moving at half speed. This is easily remedied by quickly shooting four arrows at your enemy and then moving to a safer position while your stamina regenerates. However, even when using a bow, you're prone to being swamped with monsters when entering a new map. More than half of the time you go to a new map, you're placed on top of enemies that can quickly rid you of all of your health if you don't act quickly.

After defeating a boss, you're taken back to a familiar overworld with the same, old faces ready to claw your guts out. Exploring in this game becomes a bit tedious. Many paths will lead to dead-ends, and there's no map or guidance of any sort to even point you in the direction of your next mildly-exciting dungeon. While exploring, dungeons, combat, and bosses may be lackluster and bland, you can always have a good time searching for more loot, which is randomly generated; as a wise man once said: it's like a box of chocolates; you never know what you're gonna get.

Overall, this game is bland and has very little excitement to offer. However, it is cheap, and if you love endless roguelikes with random loot, this one may be one to pick up at some point.

Pros:
Easy to play
Random world
Random loot

Cons:
Boring
Repetitive
No map
Overpowered archers
Easy bosses

After playing this game for a bit I have found it to be a rather nice little gem as it has some interesting elements to it that seem to have me currently hooked.

Okay so the pros first:
- The combat can be completley different depending on whether you chose to be long range or close up, as long range won't do as much damage but makes you safer and close up been the contrary.
- It is a nice felling when you roam a world for a while and you find a new dungeon all of a sudden, it is much like the first zelda where there is that suspense of what the next dungeon could hold. And you can take the dungeons on how ever you want to.
- The items allow for a nice mix up and with the good amount that drop over one game play it is fairly easy to find enough equipment to change from something like a mage to a swordman.
- The music fits the game perfectly and helps with making the game that more enjoyable.
- There is also some random encounters when you rest at camp fires making it rather interesting whether some physco is going to be next to you when you wake up.

And now for the negatives:
- The movement system can be a little buggy as you collide with the enviroment REALLY easy making you an easy target for enemies sometimes.
- The music will cut out when you get into an area with enemies which is all the time meaning that hlef the time your playing the game there is any music (and it's soooo good too so it's a real shame).
- There is no tutorial at the start or even anywhere in the menu to review the control scheme so my first 5 minutes of the game was trying to figure out how to actually play it.
- Now I know that this game is meant to be a bit like the first zelda with no map... But it becomes really frustrating at some points, like when you are trying to find a fire to rest next to but oh that's right there no god damn map to use so by the time I find a fire nearly all my health is gone.
- And laslty if you go melee into a boss fight it becomes really easy as you end up walking to the boss mashing the space bar (that's special btw) allowing me to hack the boss up in less than 2 minutes.

These fixes I'm sure will be coming but the game is still very enjoyable even with the problems that are still lingering in the game.

I love the art style and the music is really cool, as well as the fast-paced gameplay and the awesome loot you get!\nIf you like rogue-likes and souls games, give this one a try.

What you need to realize is that Zelda took years to make, it was so well developed that no other game can compare to it for that very reason. With that being said i find it unrealistic for people to try and compare it to a $5 game. I'm not trashing this game in any way by saying that, what I'm saying is that for what has been put into it, I feel like it exceedes my expectations. I played the first game and the second one has improved leaps and bounds. The early issues were just fixed this update, and I'm very glad that the maker is concerned with the flaws in his product, you can even look on the website to see the amazing and great things they have planned. (http://kintogames.com/) This game is worth far more than $5, for the content I would expect $10-$15 especially with what they are adding in the future. I can play hours on end of this game finding all the hidden things it has to offer. The best part is that no playthrough is ever the same thanks to the random weapon drops. I can get an OP weapon at the start and have no trouble finishing it but next time if I don't get that, the entire thing changes. This game is great. This game also should not be played with anything but a controller, it gives you the best gameplay possible. Can't wait for multiplayer!!!

bit Dungeon II is a Dark Souls take on The Legend of Zelda(1986). There are various bonfires with a few having merchants in the same screen.  There are 6 dungeons and a final dungeon consisting of two separate parts. There are 9 main Bosses and one hidden one, the Ice Golem. I have yet to find out what slaying this one does. On my second play through I noticed hidden rooms in bushes, but nowhere else. The enemies have great designs, though my favorite is the lanky, four-eyed monsters in the cursed forest followed closely by the dungeon cats. These cats show up in rooms you already cleared to tear at the remains of the fallen.
The over-world is quite small compared to The Legend of Zelda. Contrary to the main page, the temples are not randomly placed on the over-world. The dungeons themselves are fairly short and the bosses are simple and easy. I just stand there and hit them until they die, usually within 30 seconds. I have only died once at the hand of a boss. In fact I have only died 4 times total and have only one game over. The game is fairly easy and it only gets easier with high end gear. Since the loot is all randomized, I found unique items halfway through and passed on most everything else.
When first starting the game, there is a ghost of a woman who gives her soul to you for an extra life. If you die, you can return to the place of your death and reclaim her soul, very much like Dark Souls.
The second play through let me keep my gear and since the enemies don’t seem to increase very much in power, and the dungeons were exactly the same, there is very little replay value. I am currently on my third play through.
The game itself is short, a good 90 minutes long, if you don’t rush. Overall the game is a pleasant experience and worth the time for at least one play through. The 4.99 price tag is just about right, and I would strongly encourage getting it on sale or in a bundle if you are interested but are hesitant to get it full price.

reviewText:
A  simple action RPG with rogue-like elements.

Plot:

The game has very little plot to speak of, or not so much that I've been able to discover. Your objective is to take the spirit of your loved one to her grave, and to do so you'll have to kill a bunch of bosses in their dungeons, reminiscent of Shadow of the Colossus in theme except there are also ordinary enemies and minibosses.

Game world:

The game is set on an unchanging overworld map with dungeons that randomly pick from a set of designs to give a feeling of variation, taking inspiration from Souls for the bonfires scattered around where you can regain health and check your stats. The random generation is therefore not very significant.

Gameplay:

The combat is rather simple but not mindless: your character auto attacks when it bumps into enemies, but at a mouse click, key press or button push depending on what you're playing with they can attack instantly at the cost of some stamina. Holding down this key allows you to block attacks also at the cost of stamina, and perform a charged attack with your weapons. There's not much challenge to fights as the enemies and bosses are rather easy to figure out, and your greatest danger is underleveling or lack of good equipment.

The permadeath mechanic takes inspiration from Souls: the soul you're transporting is your only extra life, and you drop it at the place of your death. If you cannot retrieve it, your next death is final and you must restart, keeping only the coins you collected which can be used to purchase items at shops you must find yourself.

Graphics:

The game has charming retro" pixel sprites graphics which work pretty well. There's not much animation to the characters but not much is needed either.

Replayability:

There is NG+
date: and if you enjoy collecting rare equipment or trying out different weapons and builds there is some replayability in this for you. The game itself is short. By the time this review was written I had completed my first playthrough after somewhere around 5 restarts
recommended:
mostly late in the game. The game itself would only take around an hour to complete.

Conclusion:

This is a nice enough timewaster on a mobile platform. Outside of a mobile however

reviewText:
Really, I'm recommending bit Dungeon II as a popcorn game.  This isn't something that you'll be revisiting repeatedly over the years, and that's okay.

It plays an awful lot like an old Zelda game, except instead of a hand-crafted world and experience, you get a partially randomized set of cookie cutter areas.  And you lose your character progress if you die while trying to get back to your previous death location.  If you are looking for Zelda, look elsewhere.

At first, the game feels felt pretty hard, but as I started to understand the item system, it got a whole lot easier.  It's fun to do a few runs through the game and put it into increasingly difficult modes, but then I hit a wall.  As with many randomized games, the design does not adjust to the difficulty scaling.  In bit Dungeon II, you'll find there are certain dungeon rooms that are very small and you can spawn into a horde of enemies that simply one-shot you with no opportunity for you to react.  That's the point when I stopped enjoying myself, but I'd say the ~20 hours I played the game were well worth the low admission price.

This Game Is The Physical Being Of Perfection...

While it was interesting to try out, the game needs a revision on some of its mechanics.  The lack of any map ensures you'll spend a lot of time wandering around, and it's probably the single biggest sticking point of the game that I can think of.  Other than that, most dungeons had similar or identical layouts, and trekking back to a dungeon after a death turns into a chore when you're not positive which way to go.  After about an hour my mind started to glaze over because the game starts to numb you - each screen looks similar, contains similar enemies, and must be handled in a similar way.\n\nThe game's concept is great but it will quickly get old unless something is done in a patch to revisit some of its weaknesses.  I can't recommend the game for its full retail price, but if you're OK with paying 3 dollars or so to wring out about 2 hours of fun, then you'll have a good time.  After spending about 2 hours in the game I have no desire to continue playing it - the rogue-like elements are far from deep and the inspirations from Dark Souls and Zelda do not significantly change or improve upon aspects of those games. Instead, the very clear inspiration it takes from other games leaves these borrowed mechanics feel shallow in comparison to their use in the titles that made them classics.

All in all I think if older style of games is your thing, you should try this :)

reviewText: Addicitve zelda-style gameplay with the frantic looting aesthetic of Realm of the Mad God.  Perma-death does make the whole thing a lot more serious as well. Not as much room for mistakes.

Firstly I have to tell you about the positive parts of the game

-Positives

*It's graphics

I really like the time and effort put into the sprites for the characters as well as the monsters; especially that items change the look of the character which is a plus in most games like these.

*Game Mechanics

They feel relatively smooth and you do get feedback in the form of damage shown and what ever bonuses are applied

-Negatives

Okay, now there are a lot of negatives to this game

*Super Buggy

Now I know there is only one person working on this game but it is not fully developed, early stage Early Access at best.
_There is a bug were the character disappers (Dies) and since this is a Roguelike it's gone for good.
_The Achivements don't all work so if you are a complisionist do not buy this game because the achievement has been broken for a long time with no update in sight.
_The game is rarely updated and still feels barebones.
_Bonuses, once at a certain level, don't work together.
_Sometimes unequiping your items actually reduces your stats permanently.
_Walking through to new areas can make screen go blank and you have to close by minimising and losing progress
_No way to roll back if there are any glitches
_Can't get your soul back if you die before leaving dungeon with dead boss

This is to name a few of many more glitches and they have been around for months with no fixes at all and little communication from the developer

Areas:

The game is interesting to begin with but the areas remain the same and it feels repetative if you are on your second playthrough or on a new character. Although the game lets you go to which ever dungeon you want you need to go to them all in the end making it quite linear. Not as giant as is claimed in the description

I had some expectations of this game and would have liked to see it updated more often, since I had been active in the in discussions, but am sadly disappointed at the lack of effort going into fixing it.

I hope this has been informative and thank you for reading.

A simple and easy action-adventure RPG/dungeon crawler. Good enough pixel graphics and animations, barely any story, not much variety in puzzles/levels. Plays like a simpler Zelda with dungeons filled only with enemies, buttons, and door keys. Press every button and kill every enemy in a locked room and eventually you'll reach the end. One of the only puzzles was the 'endless maze' type of puzzle where there are multiple exits and you just go to the exit that doesn't have the bush next to it.

It's pretty good for power trips because once you power up above the difficulty curve you can just walk into most enemies and you will automatically kill them. Level ups come pretty often. There's one button to attack, charge attack, & defend. I didn't like using mouse (because you need to move the mouse cursor to face the enemy) so I just used keyboard for both positioning (and attacking always goes in the direction you face). Instead of WASD+mouse I used arrow keys + space but it may be possible to use a controller instead. It's a simple enough game to play in windowed mode while watching something else on the side.

Death is pretty forgiving as long as you stay in areas you're strong enough to get through. When you die you leave behind an extra life token. If you die before you retrieve it then it's game over. Otherwise you can die as many times as you want as long as you can retrieve the token each time. However, I've read that the final boss removes your extra life (so only one try) so be prepared for that.

I liked lifesteal + constitution/defensive stats just so it would be easier to not pay too much attention.

I ended the game at level 74 and went from a Lvl 19 Vampiric Sword of a God to a Lvl 32 Vampiric Spear of Death and skipped all other weapon drops. Once you beat the game you start again from the beginning with all your items and coins but I stopped playing so I don't know if there's anything different.

Other random thoughts:
Don't allow yourself to be surrounded, it's the easiest way to die
Sometimes you can see cracks in the wall that you can go through for a chest with a random item.
There are purple enemies that spawn in dungeons after you return to a cleared room. They often drop hp regen potions (so you can farm them to regen hp) though it seems like the regen effect doesn't last when you change rooms.
It's probably worth saving 300 black coins for a cave that sells 300-coin chests with random items. I wasted my coins on the 30-coin chests that had items I didn't even pick up. Only spend coins on other vendors if you're having trouble at the moment and need an upgrade. (Though by the time you farm the coins you'll probably be a high enough level to overpower the enemies you had trouble with)
There are a couple sound effects that seem very similar to mario sound effects
I would have liked:
A way to see the full map (not just the minimap)
To know how things worked in-game (how much do stats affect your power, what does everything mean, what stats are better to choose, difference between things (like Cleave vs Super Cleave)
Worth a look if you like simple zelda-like RPGs and like to power trip. It may be a little more difficult if you aren't a seasoned gamer but I'd say you can always grind to beat the power curve and then power-trip to the end.

reviewText:
If Zelda: Link to the Past and Dark Souls had a baby and raised it on loot-grab ARPG games like  Diablo, this is what that child would be.

Overview:
A very fast passed Zelda: A Link to The Past style of gameplay with elements from Dark Souls, and RNG loot systems like Diablo... Pretty much like what I just said above.  You'll explore a randomly generated map, happen upon dungeons to be solved and bosses therein to slay. For those that played Super Metroid on the SNES back in the day, and remember how defeating bosses are like keys in a lock to a door to a final area, you will find that homage here.  The game has a great rate of progression. Greedy loot based gamers, those that enjoy Diablo, will enjoy this game very much.

Pros:
Rogue-like risk vs. reward gameplay.
Retro graphics, but not too retro as to cause your eyes to bleed. The sprites are done beautifully, Zelda SNES style.
Awesome Chiptunes music. Very entertaining videogame/chiptunes style music. I turned off my own music just to enjoy it.
Tiered loot system. Mimics MMO's and ARPG's with its loot system. I.E. Common

bit Dungeon II is a very simple Rogue-Lite Dungeon based RPG which was likely developed with Mobile Touch/Mouse as the main control method.

Don't think that a Mobile port is always a bad thing, in fact, this game actually pulls off the mobile port somewhat right because it doesn't charge a ridiculous price like many other mobile ports.

The game is likened to the original Zelda title because of how the game is set up. There is no tutorial to tell you what to do and many people would be irritated with that fact, I actually liked journeying throughout the world trying to figure out what to do. I've gotten to what I assume is the final boss a couple times. The difficulty really depends on what drops you get because the game at its heart is a Rogue-Lite Dungeon RPG. You progress from dungeon to dungeon and fight each boss until you can get to the Final Dungeon. Sometimes you will have good runs and sometimes you will have bad runs.

The game is a little buggy but it seems that a lot of the bugs I use to experience have been patched in the past few months and that pleases me a lot to see a developer patch and support their game post release on Steam, because all too often I see games that could be very good just left as abandonware on Steam.

bit Dungeon II will remain a game that I will play periodically because of how enjoyable it is. If you enjoy Action RPGs with permadeath you will enjoy this game.

reviewText:
A very entertaining, simple and straight-forward hack n' slash. There is very little in the way of directions or guidance but such instructions are unnecessary except for the little tips on controls you can find by pressing the ESC key. In order to make it windowed, press ENTER.  moves with WASD keys, attack with mouse, special attack with SPACE, hold down mouse to block. Simple.

I'm not exactly sure what my purpose in the game is other than killing enemies and defeating dungeons in different areas that are designed around a certain color palette and elemental theme (forest, jungle, nether, ice, desert, etc.). Thankfully there are no puzzles in this game when it comes to progressing forward in the dungeons, you just have to hit every button you find, pick up the keys, unlock the doors, and keep moving.

My first run through I got to level 3 before dying. Second time was similar, as was the third and fourth time. The fifth time, however, I got through the game once and then died at Lvl 83. As you can see, it's very easy to master and the only thing stopping you from progressing is failing to pick up stronger gear that are color-coded for your convenience in regards to overall rarity and strength. White -> Blue -> Green -> Purple -> Orange -> Red. Funnily enough, White, Blue and Purple were the most commonly found in my fifth playthrough, while Green was just as rare to find as Red. Funny, eh.

Bonfires are spread throughout the lands and offer both a full restoration of health and a quick look at your stats. They have unlimited uses, which is awesome. Another thing to mention is that you will not lose all your accumulated moolah when you die as long as you don't delete your save. You do start from the beginning at Lvl. 1 with no armor or weapons, but you are seamlessly reintroduced to the beginning with some weapons being located right next to your respawn point, which allows you to get back into the action.

The bosses were fairly easy for me: Just get up close and keep wailing on them. As soon as I found a strong enough 2-Handed Axe, Hammer, or Sword I abandoned the shield in favor of pure power. I also avoided magic staffs and bows because they take up much more stamina/magic than simply swinging a sword, even if you have to get up close and personal with enemies. It's much like Hotline Miami where foes don't bother you if you just get in there quick and hit them before they hit you. They're also scaled to your level so you won't encounter the problem where you're getting barely anything for experience when you kill an enemy that you first met at the beginning of the game; everything is still a threat but much less so if you paid mind to upgrade your gear.

It's very fun and the achievements are very easy to get; in theory you could get them all in one persistent playthrough.

A failry fun & easy diversion, like a simplified easier Zelda, meant to be played in a sitting (or a few).  You get 2 lives and its over, you cannot reload from save if you die, but you can reclaim your extra life from the spot you dropped it if you venture back to the spot, can heal & save at campfires.  Fights are pretty easy, it auto-fights, but you can mash A on the gamepad to fight faster and lose less life.  I beat about 4 dungeons in the first sitting in a little over an hour.  Then I got distracted and didn't realize something was still alive and throwing fireballs at me = gameover.  I started a second play through with a little strategy, a map I found online, and am having fun.  For the price, it is a fun casual game for a diversion.  The randomized items / weapons make it interesting to inspect drops.  I'll play it again next time for a break between other games.\n\nRuns perfectly find on my Alienware Alpha (i7) with Windows 10, full screen on my 47 TV
date: and using an xbox gamepad.  It didn't listen to the controller thumsticks for a minute
recommended: but after pressing a button it worked great."

reviewText:
bit Dungeon II is a Link to the Past meets the Souls series(as in Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, not as in Soul Blazer) with the original Grandia leveling system.

If those are games that you love then definitely check out bit Dungeon II.

There is definitely some buginess to the game(bosses and invaders tend to lag when starting their dialog. Sometimes the controls will lock up when the randomized loot is generating), but overall the bugs do not ruin the experience.

Gear is also nearly 100% random, with the only exceptions being certain basic gear vendors, so planning to level up your character a certain way from the beginning may ultimately cause more harm than good depending on the RNG.

For your first few attempts, try to be fluid in your character build, trying out all of the different weapon types and deciding on your preferred playstyle, then attempt a true build once you understand how the character building works.

::FROM THIS POINT ON I WILL BE WRITING A SHORT PRIMER ON CHARCTER BUILDING. FEEL FREE TO STOP READING IF YOU PREFER TO FIGURE THESE THINGS OUT ON YOUR OWN::

The character building is surprisingly deep, despite the simplicity of this game.

Like in the original Grandia, each weapon type is linked to two or more stats(daggers are dexterity weapons, great axes are strength weapons, staves are intelligence weapons, etc), so if you level up while using a weapon with a particular stat focus, then your character will gain additional points to that stat(all weapon types increase constitution as well).

The Souls games influence much of bit Dungeon 2, but in terms of character building, the Souls series influence is apparent in the weapon damage scaling.

Weapon damage is improved based on the stats that are attributed to it(these appear on the bottom of each weapon's stat description, annotated with an asterisk*), so a weak dexterity weapon like a dagger will generally be far more effective on a character with high dexterity than a much stronger weapon that does not use dexterity to scale its damage.

Of course, you can find an off build weapon that is powerful enough to outclass build centric weapons, but these should be avoided during early leveling if you have already increased a particular stat upwards of 50 points, since focussing on a new stat after that much investment may impede your character's growth, and keep them from getting strong enough to stay competitive as enemies get stronger.

Final note: Every enemy in the game scales with your character's level, and you can level your character well beyond level 100.

reviewText:
This game was an adventure for $0.99. Not bad.
bit Dungeon II was worth the playthrough. The game had a simple combat system, that let you focus on exploring the bitland world and finding cool loot along the way. The different classes have simple abilities that you change based on your weapon. The rpg based stats determine how much damage you do with each weapon, and how much of a special attribute such as crit you obtain. I enjoyed the layout of the map, and the set up of the bosses. Dungeons made me think a little bit with their mazelike nature. Zzzzzzzz. The bosses. Zzzzzz. The bosses really weren't very interesting. The creeps along the way to the bosses are, with some of them appearing out of nowhere or shooting magic missles. Most bosses are defeated just by dodging during the missle cycle, then mashing spacebar while they aren't attacking. My Dex playthrough proved to be WAAY too easy once I obtained the bow and arrow. The first runthrough can be completed in about an 2 hours if run perfectly. There are lots of little secrets to how the game works, that should be found out on your own, but the puzzles are infuriating, so I'd like to offer a tip IF YOU WANT IT.  The mazes can be solved by finding a wisened man or elf who tells you the way, but funfact, just go where there isn't a pillar. That usually solves the puzzle.  Overall the game was pretty decent. This game has replayability if you get really into it, but I was content with being done after the first playthough. Pick this game up on sale. IF not, be understanding with the short runtime. This adventure has very little story, but definitley has feeling. I enjoyed my playthrough, but will likely never play the game again.

bit Dungeon II is a very simple Rogue-Lite Dungeon based RPG which was likely developed with Mobile Touch/Mouse as the main control method.

Don't think that a Mobile port is always a bad thing, in fact, this game actually pulls off the mobile port somewhat right because it doesn't charge a ridiculous price like many other mobile ports.

The game is likened to the original Zelda title because of how the game is set up. There is no tutorial to tell you what to do and many people would be irritated with that fact, I actually liked journeying throughout the world trying to figure out what to do. I've gotten to what I assume is the final boss a couple times. The difficulty really depends on what drops you get because the game at its heart is a Rogue-Lite Dungeon RPG. You progress from dungeon to dungeon and fight each boss until you can get to the Final Dungeon. Sometimes you will have good runs and sometimes you will have bad runs.

The game is a little buggy but it seems that a lot of the bugs I use to experience have been patched in the past few months and that pleases me a lot to see a developer patch and support their game post release on Steam, because all too often I see games that could be very good just left as abandonware on Steam.

bit Dungeon II will remain a game that I will play periodically because of how enjoyable it is. If you enjoy Action RPGs with permadeath you will enjoy this game.

Doesn't require a deep amount of investment.  Get it on sale.

About the game
This a solid, rougue-like RPG with a surprising amount amount of gameplay for £2.75. The combat system is simple (as in walk in to someone and mash the space bar or left click), but some fight will need to be thought out a bit, like my favourite boss, Leontocephaline. This is boss in so definitely not enfuriating that you can't kill him before he does his very underpowered move where he fires a laser that kills you in a couple of seconds. Other than him, all the bosses don't feel too strong and overpowered and the loot that you get in the chest after them will always be decent. It can be a little boring when you get a strong weapon at a low level, but that doesn't happen very often.

In my opion, the only bad thing about the game is that you can't expand the map at all, but I would expect that to be added in eventually.


Achievements
I am a reliable source because I 100% complete the game, which to be completely honest, isn't too hard. 12/15 of the achievements you will get by just killing the final boss and the other 3 are kind of easy to get. You should atempt the dying achievement as soon as you start so that you don't have to end a good run later on. Finding an epic quality weapon should just happen eventually. After killing a boss, you will get a black chest in the next room that guarantees a puple or higher rarity item. After one of the last 2 bosses before the final boss, a red chest will drop that is guaranteed to contain a red item. Remember that epic quality is red and it has to be a weapon. The other achievement makes you kill 100 of the purple dogs that spawn in dungeon rooms that you have cleared. This one will also happen eventually because you will end up going between 2 rooms and killing the Fiends that spawn for health potions.

Conclusion
An amazing game that deserves the attention of more people. If you're a scrub with a bad PC, I think there is a moblie version that is like a quid or something. Doesn't get repetitive ever and is almost always fair with RNG and enemy spawns.

First off, I love bit dungeon. I play it all the time. So when I saw BD2 i had to buy it of course.
First impressions were good. It's not the same as the first game, but still enjoyable and much more varied.

My first problem is that other then in fortresses, i didn't find a way to regain your health, only by killing the purple demons who appear in rooms you already killed everyone in. If you are just running around outside as you most likely are, there is no way to replenish your health.

Another problem is that often you manage to click and change your weapon to one that's just laying around without noticing it.


The bigest issue though is that it's buggy.
Often when you walk around the screen keeps jutting and shaking as you go, and I'm not sure if it's only on my PC or everyone finds this, but often when you pick up a weapon, the associated special attack doesn't work well. (sometimes it works on one screen and stops working on the next)
This wouldn't be that big a deal, but I accidentally switched my ice hammer off for an ice cube.
The ice cube didn't reside in the weapon slot, but still i couldn't carry it at the same time as I carried my weapon.

So i accidentally picked up the ice cube that was right next to the door and then left the room... Returning instantly I found my 25+ atk weapon has disappeared, and I was left with an icecube that had NO powers. I couldn'T even get out of the sewers/catacombs under the fortress as I had no means of attacking. This is a huge issue because of course i was forced to let the monsters kill me and go back from lv 19 or 20 to lv 1 and start the game over.

--------

So can I recommend it?

It is a really nice looking game if you like the art style. It is in the same style as Bit Dungeon, just way more varied, more in depth and less repetative. It has a nice variety of style through the overall map, and it's procedurally generated meaning you'll have different worlds every time you start a new game.

It is also kinda buggy, The controls are a bit weird, not very responsive, sometimes I click an enemy to hit it but my guy just walks there, or I am in the middle of a bunch of monsters, my special attack doesn't fire and even if I'm clicking I'm just changing my weapon to the one right next to me and just get mobbed and killed in seconds. Also I found no way to replenish your life outside of fortresses.

Honestly, If I wasn't such a huge fan of Bit Dungeon I probably wouldn't like it that much.
So I'll recommend it but only half heartedly. Only buy this if you really really like the style!

It's been out on steam for over a year now, I hope these bugs will get fixed soon so I could give it a higher score.

reviewText:
This game was an adventure for $0.99. Not bad.
bit Dungeon II was worth the playthrough. The game had a simple combat system, that let you focus on exploring the bitland world and finding cool loot along the way. The different classes have simple abilities that you change based on your weapon. The rpg based stats determine how much damage you do with each weapon, and how much of a special attribute such as crit you obtain. I enjoyed the layout of the map, and the set up of the bosses. Dungeons made me think a little bit with their mazelike nature. Zzzzzzzz. The bosses. Zzzzzz. The bosses really weren't very interesting. The creeps along the way to the bosses are, with some of them appearing out of nowhere or shooting magic missles. Most bosses are defeated just by dodging during the missle cycle, then mashing spacebar while they aren't attacking. My Dex playthrough proved to be WAAY too easy once I obtained the bow and arrow. The first runthrough can be completed in about an 2 hours if run perfectly. There are lots of little secrets to how the game works, that should be found out on your own, but the puzzles are infuriating, so I'd like to offer a tip IF YOU WANT IT.  The mazes can be solved by finding a wisened man or elf who tells you the way, but funfact, just go where there isn't a pillar. That usually solves the puzzle.  Overall the game was pretty decent. This game has replayability if you get really into it, but I was content with being done after the first playthough. Pick this game up on sale. IF not, be understanding with the short runtime. This adventure has very little story, but definitley has feeling. I enjoyed my playthrough, but will likely never play the game again.

bit Dungeon II is a Link to the Past meets the Souls series(as in Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, not as in Soul Blazer) with the original Grandia leveling system.

If those are games that you love then definitely check out bit Dungeon II.

There is definitely some buginess to the game(bosses and invaders tend to lag when starting their dialog. Sometimes the controls will lock up when the randomized loot is generating), but overall the bugs do not ruin the experience.

Gear is also nearly 100% random, with the only exceptions being certain basic gear vendors, so planning to level up your character a certain way from the beginning may ultimately cause more harm than good depending on the RNG.

For your first few attempts, try to be fluid in your character build, trying out all of the different weapon types and deciding on your preferred playstyle, then attempt a true build once you understand how the character building works.

::FROM THIS POINT ON I WILL BE WRITING A SHORT PRIMER ON CHARCTER BUILDING. FEEL FREE TO STOP READING IF YOU PREFER TO FIGURE THESE THINGS OUT ON YOUR OWN::

The character building is surprisingly deep, despite the simplicity of this game.

Like in the original Grandia, each weapon type is linked to two or more stats(daggers are dexterity weapons, great axes are strength weapons, staves are intelligence weapons, etc), so if you level up while using a weapon with a particular stat focus, then your character will gain additional points to that stat(all weapon types increase constitution as well).

The Souls games influence much of bit Dungeon 2, but in terms of character building, the Souls series influence is apparent in the weapon damage scaling.

Weapon damage is improved based on the stats that are attributed to it(these appear on the bottom of each weapon's stat description, annotated with an asterisk*), so a weak dexterity weapon like a dagger will generally be far more effective on a character with high dexterity than a much stronger weapon that does not use dexterity to scale its damage.

Of course, you can find an off build weapon that is powerful enough to outclass build centric weapons, but these should be avoided during early leveling if you have already increased a particular stat upwards of 50 points, since focussing on a new stat after that much investment may impede your character's growth, and keep them from getting strong enough to stay competitive as enemies get stronger.

Final note: Every enemy in the game scales with your character's level, and you can level your character well beyond level 100.

bit Dungeon II is a simplified rogue-like game with a few souls-like elements.

It looks good, has a pleasent pixel style. Your progress only shown on a minimap, so a mental map is pretty much needed for navigating through the maze-like world. Creature variation is good enough. They mostly behave the same way, but there a few special units needing different approach.
The gameplay/combat however is so simple, that there is no real way of being good at this game. There are a few actions aside from walking into enemies and auto-attack them, but in a rogue-like where you can die and lose almost everything there is not enough control. Boss fights are poorly developed. You just have to have proper gear and basically run into them until the special attack kicks in and the boss dies.
Enemies level up with you (at least that is what i think anyway) so there is no reason to grind for xp. Items can be collected, these are the things which can make a difference, but drops are extremely random (after i died the first time on level 43 i found a legendary lvl17 staff in the open after a few minutes at level 6, the best weapon since I played the game). There are rooms scathered in the world where you can pick a stat bonus for yourself, when you level up you gain stats automatically. Black coins can be gathered from chests and fallen foes, which can be carried over through incarnations". I recently found a room with epic chests which can be opened via coins. There are also lesser starter items available in these "shops" available on the cheap.

Overall
date: bit Dungeon II is an enjoyable title for a few hours
recommended: worth a try if you already have it
hoursPlayed: but it cannot be taken seriously in the end due to its random nature. This is one of those (nowadays pretty frequent) occasions where features were so simplified that in the end it hurts the game itself. I would say the game is too casual
